This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy. In the past, a version of anatomy best described as nonfunctional anatomy taught us how a muscle acted to move an isolated joint. This could also be called origin-insertion anatomy, and it worked fairly well in describing potential movement of a cadaver on a table or on a skeleton model. Origin-insertion anatomy required the memorization of where a muscle started (its origin) and ended (its insertion) and its isolated action. No thought was given to what the muscle did when a person was standing or engaged in locomotion. In contrast, functional anatomy describes how muscles act to move interrelated groups of joints and muscles working together to perform movements. In functional anatomical terms, Gray described the actions of the lower extremity during locomotion as follows. When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground.
This resulted from misperceptions based on lack of information and limited exposure.
This resulted from misperceptions based on lack of information and limited exposure. So, in some circles, functional training was synonymous with balance exercises and stability balls.
This resulted from misperceptions based on lack of information and limited exposure. So, in some circles, functional training was synonymous with balance exercises and stability balls. This seemed like common sense and difficult to argue with.
This resulted from misperceptions based on lack of information and limited exposure. So, in some circles, functional training was synonymous with balance exercises and stability balls. This seemed like common sense and difficult to argue with. But many coaches viewed functional training as a move away from bilateral lifting and barbells and a move toward athletes and clients lifting light weights on balance boards and balls.
This resulted from misperceptions based on lack of information and limited exposure. So, in some circles, functional training was synonymous with balance exercises and stability balls. This seemed like common sense and difficult to argue with. But many coaches viewed functional training as a move away from bilateral lifting and barbells and a move toward athletes and clients lifting light weights on balance boards and balls. Surprisingly, however, some coaches who have embraced functional training espouse concepts that, in the initial analysis, appear nonfunctional.

Surprisingly, however, some coaches who have embraced functional training espouse concepts that, in the initial analysis, appear nonfunctional. This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field.

Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility.

This resulted from misperceptions based on lack of information and limited exposure. So, in some circles, functional training was synonymous with balance exercises and stability balls. But many coaches viewed functional training as a move away from bilateral lifting and barbells and a move toward athletes and clients lifting light weights on balance boards and balls. This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion.
This resulted from misperceptions based on lack of information and limited exposure. So, in some circles, functional training was synonymous with balance exercises and stability balls. This seemed like common sense and difficult to argue with. But many coaches viewed functional training as a move away from bilateral lifting and barbells and a move toward athletes and clients lifting light weights on balance boards and balls. Surprisingly, however, some coaches who have embraced functional training espouse concepts that, in the initial analysis, appear nonfunctional. This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion. In many cases, in the effort to make everything functional, coaches and athletes ended up neglecting the important stabilizing functions of certain muscle groups.

This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization.
This seemed like common sense and difficult to argue with. But many coaches viewed functional training as a move away from bilateral lifting and barbells and a move toward athletes and clients lifting light weights on balance boards and balls. Surprisingly, however, some coaches who have embraced functional training espouse concepts that, in the initial analysis, appear nonfunctional. This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion.
This seemed like common sense and difficult to argue with. But many coaches viewed functional training as a move away from bilateral lifting and barbells and a move toward athletes and clients lifting light weights on balance boards and balls. Surprisingly, however, some coaches who have embraced functional training espouse concepts that, in the initial analysis, appear nonfunctional. This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion. In many cases, in the effort to make everything functional, coaches and athletes ended up neglecting the important stabilizing functions of certain muscle groups.
This seemed like common sense and difficult to argue with. But many coaches viewed functional training as a move away from bilateral lifting and barbells and a move toward athletes and clients lifting light weights on balance boards and balls. Surprisingly, however, some coaches who have embraced functional training espouse concepts that, in the initial analysis, appear nonfunctional. This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion. In many cases, in the effort to make everything functional, coaches and athletes ended up neglecting the important stabilizing functions of certain muscle groups. For some athletes the development of stability at the hip may initially require isolated hip work to properly turn on, or activate, the muscles.
This seemed like common sense and difficult to argue with. But many coaches viewed functional training as a move away from bilateral lifting and barbells and a move toward athletes and clients lifting light weights on balance boards and balls. Surprisingly, however, some coaches who have embraced functional training espouse concepts that, in the initial analysis, appear nonfunctional. This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion. In many cases, in the effort to make everything functional, coaches and athletes ended up neglecting the important stabilizing functions of certain muscle groups. For some athletes the development of stability at the hip may initially require isolated hip work to properly turn on, or activate, the muscles. Performance expert Mark Verstegen of EXOS (formerly Athletes' Performance) in Phoenix, Arizona, refers to this concept as isolation for innervation.

The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. In many cases, in the effort to make everything functional, coaches and athletes ended up neglecting the important stabilizing functions of certain muscle groups. For some athletes the development of stability at the hip may initially require isolated hip work to properly turn on, or activate, the muscles. Performance expert Mark Verstegen of EXOS (formerly Athletes' Performance) in Phoenix, Arizona, refers to this concept as isolation for innervation.
This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion. In many cases, in the effort to make everything functional, coaches and athletes ended up neglecting the important stabilizing functions of certain muscle groups. For some athletes the development of stability at the hip may initially require isolated hip work to properly turn on, or activate, the muscles. Performance expert Mark Verstegen of EXOS (formerly Athletes' Performance) in Phoenix, Arizona, refers to this concept as isolation for innervation. At certain times, certain muscle groups—notably the deep abdominals, hip abductors, and scapular stabilizers— need to be isolated to improve their function.
This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion. In many cases, in the effort to make everything functional, coaches and athletes ended up neglecting the important stabilizing functions of certain muscle groups. For some athletes the development of stability at the hip may initially require isolated hip work to properly turn on, or activate, the muscles. Performance expert Mark Verstegen of EXOS (formerly Athletes' Performance) in Phoenix, Arizona, refers to this concept as isolation for innervation. At certain times, certain muscle groups—notably the deep abdominals, hip abductors, and scapular stabilizers— need to be isolated to improve their function. For this reason, some apparently nonfunctional single-joint exercises may in fact improve function of the entire lower extremity.
This use of apparently nonfunctional exercises by supposed proponents of functional training caused some confusion in the field. Exercises that promote the function of joints that require stabilization are different from exercises that promote the function of joints that strive for mobility. The primary function of certain muscles and muscle groups is stabilization. Functional training for those muscles involves training them to be better stabilizers, often by performing simple exercises through small ranges of motion. In many cases, in the effort to make everything functional, coaches and athletes ended up neglecting the important stabilizing functions of certain muscle groups. For some athletes the development of stability at the hip may initially require isolated hip work to properly turn on, or activate, the muscles. Performance expert Mark Verstegen of EXOS (formerly Athletes' Performance) in Phoenix, Arizona, refers to this concept as isolation for innervation. At certain times, certain muscle groups—notably the deep abdominals, hip abductors, and scapular stabilizers— need to be isolated to improve their function. For this reason, some apparently nonfunctional single-joint exercises may in fact improve function of the entire lower extremity. This is one of the paradoxes of functional training.
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions.
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down?
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down? As far as I can tell, only a few sports, such as rowing, are performed from a seated position.
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down? As far as I can tell, only a few sports, such as rowing, are performed from a seated position. If we accept this premise, we can see that training muscles from a seated position would not be functional for most sports.
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down? As far as I can tell, only a few sports, such as rowing, are performed from a seated position. If we accept this premise, we can see that training muscles from a seated position would not be functional for most sports. How many sports are played in a rigid environment where stability is pro-vided by outside sources?
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down? As far as I can tell, only a few sports, such as rowing, are performed from a seated position. If we accept this premise, we can see that training muscles from a seated position would not be functional for most sports. How many sports are played in a rigid environment where stability is pro-vided by outside sources? The answer would appear to be none.
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down? If we accept this premise, we can see that training muscles from a seated position would not be functional for most sports. To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down? As far as I can tell, only a few sports, such as rowing, are performed from a seated position. If we accept this premise, we can see that training muscles from a seated position would not be functional for most sports. How many sports are played in a rigid environment where stability is pro-vided by outside sources? The answer would appear to be none. Most sports are contested on fields or courts. The stability is provided by the athlete, not by some outside source.
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down? As far as I can tell, only a few sports, such as rowing, are performed from a seated position. If we accept this premise, we can see that training muscles from a seated position would not be functional for most sports. How many sports are played in a rigid environment where stability is pro-vided by outside sources? The answer would appear to be none. Most sports are contested on fields or courts. The stability is provided by the athlete, not by some outside source. Reasoning again would tell us that most machine-based training systems are not by definition functional because the load is stabilized for the lifter by the machine.
To better understand the concept of functional training, ask yourself a few simple questions. How many sports are played sitting down? As far as I can tell, only a few sports, such as rowing, are performed from a seated position. If we accept this premise, we can see that training muscles from a seated position would not be functional for most sports. How many sports are played in a rigid environment where stability is pro-vided by outside sources? The answer would appear to be none. Most sports are contested on fields or courts. The stability is provided by the athlete, not by some outside source. Reasoning again would tell us that most machine-based training systems are not by definition functional because the load is stabilized for the lifter by the machine. Proponents of machine-based training systems might argue that machine-based training is safer, but there is a clear trade-off for relative safety in the weight room.
To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground.

The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional.

The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work.

The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work. Gary Gray's work was the catalyst for this change.
To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work. Gary Gray's work was the catalyst for this change. The shift originated from the physical therapy profession, but the concept of functional training has slowly been adopted by both strength and conditioning coaches and personal trainers.
To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work. Gary Gray's work was the catalyst for this change. The shift originated from the physical therapy profession, but the concept of functional training has slowly been adopted by both strength and conditioning coaches and personal trainers. It might be helpful to view strength training as a continuum, with Gray's multiplane approach on one end and the Westside Barbell powerlifting approach on the other.
To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work. Gary Gray's work was the catalyst for this change. The shift originated from the physical therapy profession, but the concept of functional training has slowly been adopted by both strength and conditioning coaches and personal trainers. It might be helpful to view strength training as a continuum, with Gray's multiplane approach on one end and the Westside Barbell powerlifting approach on the other. The reason behind the explosive growth and rapid acceptance of functional training is simple: It makes sense to coaches and athletes and is verified from their experience in the training room and on the court, track, or field.
To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work. Gary Gray's work was the catalyst for this change. The shift originated from the physical therapy profession, but the concept of functional training has slowly been adopted by both strength and conditioning coaches and personal trainers. It might be helpful to view strength training as a continuum, with Gray's multiplane approach on one end and the Westside Barbell powerlifting approach on the other. The reason behind the explosive growth and rapid acceptance of functional training is simple: It makes sense to coaches and athletes and is verified from their experience in the training room and on the court, track, or field. One of the first signs that functional training was here to stay was that the large manufacturers of the previously popular single-joint, muscle-isolating strength training machines began to introduce what they called ground-based machines and also began to manufacture basic squat racks and weight benches.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy. In the past, a version of anatomy best described as nonfunctional anatomy taught us how a muscle acted to move an isolated joint.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy. In the past, a version of anatomy best described as nonfunctional anatomy taught us how a muscle acted to move an isolated joint. This could also be called origin-insertion anatomy, and it worked fairly well in describing potential movement of a cadaver on a table or on a skeleton model.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy. In the past, a version of anatomy best described as nonfunctional anatomy taught us how a muscle acted to move an isolated joint. This could also be called origin-insertion anatomy, and it worked fairly well in describing potential movement of a cadaver on a table or on a skeleton model. Origin-insertion anatomy required the memorization of where a muscle started (its origin) and ended (its insertion) and its isolated action.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy. In the past, a version of anatomy best described as nonfunctional anatomy taught us how a muscle acted to move an isolated joint. This could also be called origin-insertion anatomy, and it worked fairly well in describing potential movement of a cadaver on a table or on a skeleton model. Origin-insertion anatomy required the memorization of where a muscle started (its origin) and ended (its insertion) and its isolated action. No thought was given to what the muscle did when a person was standing or engaged in locomotion.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy. In the past, a version of anatomy best described as nonfunctional anatomy taught us how a muscle acted to move an isolated joint. This could also be called origin-insertion anatomy, and it worked fairly well in describing potential movement of a cadaver on a table or on a skeleton model. Origin-insertion anatomy required the memorization of where a muscle started (its origin) and ended (its insertion) and its isolated action. No thought was given to what the muscle did when a person was standing or engaged in locomotion. In contrast, functional anatomy describes how muscles act to move interrelated groups of joints and muscles working together to perform movements.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy. In the past, a version of anatomy best described as nonfunctional anatomy taught us how a muscle acted to move an isolated joint. This could also be called origin-insertion anatomy, and it worked fairly well in describing potential movement of a cadaver on a table or on a skeleton model. Origin-insertion anatomy required the memorization of where a muscle started (its origin) and ended (its insertion) and its isolated action. No thought was given to what the muscle did when a person was standing or engaged in locomotion. In contrast, functional anatomy describes how muscles act to move interrelated groups of joints and muscles working together to perform movements. In functional anatomical terms, Gray described the actions of the lower extremity during locomotion as follows.
To truly grasp the concept of functional training it is necessary to accept a new paradigm to explain movement. This new paradigm was first introduced by physical therapist Gary Gray in his Chain Reaction courses in the 1990s. Gray promoted a new view of muscle function based not on the old definitions of flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction but on operation of kinetic chains and the science of functional anatomy. In the past, a version of anatomy best described as nonfunctional anatomy taught us how a muscle acted to move an isolated joint. This could also be called origin-insertion anatomy, and it worked fairly well in describing potential movement of a cadaver on a table or on a skeleton model. Origin-insertion anatomy required the memorization of where a muscle started (its origin) and ended (its insertion) and its isolated action. No thought was given to what the muscle did when a person was standing or engaged in locomotion. In contrast, functional anatomy describes how muscles act to move interrelated groups of joints and muscles working together to perform movements. In functional anatomical terms, Gray described the actions of the lower extremity during locomotion as follows. When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function.

Craven Fear slunk away like a whipped cur, actually running from the village instead of toward it, not knowing where he was going, urged by one instinct alone, to find a place of safety. Much-Afraid burst into tears.
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional.
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13).
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13). From the answers to those three questions we could probably agree that functional training is best characterized by exercises done with the feet in contact with the ground and, with few exceptions, without the aid of machines.
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13). From the answers to those three questions we could probably agree that functional training is best characterized by exercises done with the feet in contact with the ground and, with few exceptions, without the aid of machines. Resistance to the concept of functional training often lies in the idea that we have always done it this way.
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13). From the answers to those three questions we could probably agree that functional training is best characterized by exercises done with the feet in contact with the ground and, with few exceptions, without the aid of machines. Resistance to the concept of functional training often lies in the idea that we have always done it this way. But, as Lee Cockrell appropriately asked in his book Creating Magic, What if the way we have always done it was wrong?
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13). From the answers to those three questions we could probably agree that functional training is best characterized by exercises done with the feet in contact with the ground and, with few exceptions, without the aid of machines. Resistance to the concept of functional training often lies in the idea that we have always done it this way. But, as Lee Cockrell appropriately asked in his book Creating Magic, What if the way we have always done it was wrong? In its most basic application, a functional training program prepares an athlete to play his sport.
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13). From the answers to those three questions we could probably agree that functional training is best characterized by exercises done with the feet in contact with the ground and, with few exceptions, without the aid of machines. Resistance to the concept of functional training often lies in the idea that we have always done it this way. But, as Lee Cockrell appropriately asked in his book Creating Magic, What if the way we have always done it was wrong? In its most basic application, a functional training program prepares an athlete to play his sport. Functional training is not about using one sport to train an athlete for another sport.
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13). From the answers to those three questions we could probably agree that functional training is best characterized by exercises done with the feet in contact with the ground and, with few exceptions, without the aid of machines. Resistance to the concept of functional training often lies in the idea that we have always done it this way. In its most basic application, a functional training program prepares an athlete to play his sport. Functional training is not about using one sport to train an athlete for another sport. That’s cross-training.
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13). From the answers to those three questions we could probably agree that functional training is best characterized by exercises done with the feet in contact with the ground and, with few exceptions, without the aid of machines. Resistance to the concept of functional training often lies in the idea that we have always done it this way. But, as Lee Cockrell appropriately asked in his book Creating Magic, What if the way we have always done it was wrong? In its most basic application, a functional training program prepares an athlete to play his sport. Functional training is not about using one sport to train an athlete for another sport. That’s cross-training. Many collegiate strength programs confuse the two and, as a result, train their athletes to be powerlifters and Olympic-style weightlifters as much as they do to excel in their primary sports.
Vern Gambetta and Gary Gray, two widely recognized experts on functional training, state, Single joint movements that isolate a specific muscle are very non functional. Multi-joint movements which integrate muscle groups into movement patterns are very functional (2002, paragraph 13). From the answers to those three questions we could probably agree that functional training is best characterized by exercises done with the feet in contact with the ground and, with few exceptions, without the aid of machines. Resistance to the concept of functional training often lies in the idea that we have always done it this way. But, as Lee Cockrell appropriately asked in his book Creating Magic, What if the way we have always done it was wrong? In its most basic application, a functional training program prepares an athlete to play his sport. Functional training is not about using one sport to train an athlete for another sport. That’s cross-training. Many collegiate strength programs confuse the two and, as a result, train their athletes to be powerlifters and Olympic-style weightlifters as much as they do to excel in their primary sports. Functional training on the other hand uses many concepts developed by sport coaches to train speed, strength, and power in order to improve sport performance and reduce incidence of injury.
We chose brief twice-weekly workouts focusing on the basic push, pull, knee dominant, hip dominant, core theme, to be repeated over and over.
We chose brief twice-weekly workouts focusing on the basic push, pull, knee dominant, hip dominant, core theme, to be repeated over and over. Because judo is a year-round sport, the program was a version of the basic two- day programs you will see in the last chapter.
We chose brief twice-weekly workouts focusing on the basic push, pull, knee dominant, hip dominant, core theme, to be repeated over and over. Because judo is a year-round sport, the program was a version of the basic two- day programs you will see in the last chapter. There was very little attempt to imitate judo and a strong emphasis on the basics of strength and conditioning as we see them.
We chose brief twice-weekly workouts focusing on the basic push, pull, knee dominant, hip dominant, core theme, to be repeated over and over. Because judo is a year-round sport, the program was a version of the basic two- day programs you will see in the last chapter. There was very little attempt to imitate judo and a strong emphasis on the basics of strength and conditioning as we see them. A typical training day for Kayla consisted of the following: Foam roller Stretching Dynamic warm-up Power: medicine ball drills and plyometric Strength: push (dumbbell bench press), pull (ring row), knee dominant (single-leg squat), and hip dominant (single-leg straight-leg deadlift)Core: done between sets (basic exercises such as plank, side plank, and carries)Conditioning: specific four-minute bouts that match the energy demands of judo, done primarily on a stationary bike to save joint stres.

Program built around actions that do not occur in sport simply does not make sense. The key is to design programs that truly prepare athletes for their sports. This can be done only by using exercises that train the muscles the same way they are used in sport—in other words, through functional training.

Program built around actions that do not occur in sport simply does not make sense. The key is to design programs that truly prepare athletes for their sports. This can be done only by using exercises that train the muscles the same way they are used in sport—in other words, through functional training. For the strength and conditioning professional, the number one goal of a strength and conditioning program should be injury reduction. In professional sports, the success or failure of the strength and conditioning program is measured by player health more than by wins and losses. NFL football uses a stat called starters games missed, baseball monitors days on the disabled list, and hockey looks at man games lost to injury.
When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running.
When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action.
When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform).
When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground.
When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional.

When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional.
When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work.
When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work. Gary Gray's work was the catalyst for this change.
When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work. Gary Gray's work was the catalyst for this change. The shift originated from the physical therapy profession, but the concept of functional training has slowly been adopted by both strength and conditioning coaches and personal trainers.
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function.
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground.
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground. This concept is a difficult one to accept for those who have learned conventional origin-insertion anatomy, but on further review, it makes perfect sense.
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground. This concept is a difficult one to accept for those who have learned conventional origin-insertion anatomy, but on further review, it makes perfect sense. In the landing phase of sprinting, is the quadriceps a knee extensor?
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground. This concept is a difficult one to accept for those who have learned conventional origin-insertion anatomy, but on further review, it makes perfect sense. In the landing phase of sprinting, is the quadriceps a knee extensor? No, when the foot hits the ground the quadriceps is actually contracting eccentrically to prevent knee flexion.
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground. This concept is a difficult one to accept for those who have learned conventional origin-insertion anatomy, but on further review, it makes perfect sense. In the landing phase of sprinting, is the quadriceps a knee extensor? No, when the foot hits the ground the quadriceps is actually contracting eccentrically to prevent knee flexion. Are the hamstrings a knee flexor?
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground. This concept is a difficult one to accept for those who have learned conventional origin-insertion anatomy, but on further review, it makes perfect sense. In the landing phase of sprinting, is the quadriceps a knee extensor? No, when the foot hits the ground the quadriceps is actually contracting eccentrically to prevent knee flexion. Are the hamstrings a knee flexor? The hamstrings in fact are acting in a dual role to prevent both knee flexion and hip flexion.
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground. This concept is a difficult one to accept for those who have learned conventional origin-insertion anatomy, but on further review, it makes perfect sense. In the landing phase of sprinting, is the quadriceps a knee extensor? No, when the foot hits the ground the quadriceps is actually contracting eccentrically to prevent knee flexion. Are the hamstrings a knee flexor? The hamstrings in fact are acting in a dual role to prevent both knee flexion and hip flexion. As you think this through, the answer becomes more obvious and correspondingly easier to accept.
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground. This concept is a difficult one to accept for those who have learned conventional origin-insertion anatomy, but on further review, it makes perfect sense. In the landing phase of sprinting, is the quadriceps a knee extensor? No, when the foot hits the ground the quadriceps is actually contracting eccentrically to prevent knee flexion. Are the hamstrings a knee flexor? The hamstrings in fact are acting in a dual role to prevent both knee flexion and hip flexion. As you think this through, the answer becomes more obvious and correspondingly easier to accept. In the landing phase of walking or running, all the muscles of the lower extremity act in concert to prevent an action, not to cause one.
When the foot hits the ground, every muscle from the trunk down has one simple function. The muscles of the lower body (glutes, quads, hamstrings) all act together to stop the ankle, knee, and hip from bending in order to prevent falling to the ground. This concept is a difficult one to accept for those who have learned conventional origin-insertion anatomy, but on further review, it makes perfect sense. In the landing phase of sprinting, is the quadriceps a knee extensor? No, when the foot hits the ground the quadriceps is actually contracting eccentrically to prevent knee flexion. Are the hamstrings a knee flexor? The hamstrings in fact are acting in a dual role to prevent both knee flexion and hip flexion. As you think this through, the answer becomes more obvious and correspondingly easier to accept. In the landing phase of walking or running, all the muscles of the lower extremity act in concert to prevent an action, not to cause one. All the muscles eccentrically (by lengthening) decelerate, or slow down, flexion at the ankle, knee, and hip.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father. Then he pressed the thorn into her heart.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father. Then he pressed the thorn into her heart. It was true, just as he had said, it did cause a piercing pain, but it slipped in quickly and then, suddenly, a sweetness she had never felt or imagined before tingled through her.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father. Then he pressed the thorn into her heart. It was true, just as he had said, it did cause a piercing pain, but it slipped in quickly and then, suddenly, a sweetness she had never felt or imagined before tingled through her. It was bittersweet, but the sweetness was the stronger.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father. Then he pressed the thorn into her heart. It was true, just as he had said, it did cause a piercing pain, but it slipped in quickly and then, suddenly, a sweetness she had never felt or imagined before tingled through her. It was bittersweet, but the sweetness was the stronger. She thought of the Shepherd's words, It is so happy to love, and her pale, sallow cheeks suddenly glowed pink and her eyes shone.

For a moment Much-Afraid did not look afraid at all.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father. Then he pressed the thorn into her heart. It was true, just as he had said, it did cause a piercing pain, but it slipped in quickly and then, suddenly, a sweetness she had never felt or imagined before tingled through her. It was bittersweet, but the sweetness was the stronger. She thought of the Shepherd's words, It is so happy to love, and her pale, sallow cheeks suddenly glowed pink and her eyes shone. For a moment Much-Afraid did not look afraid at all. The twisted mouth had relaxed into a happy curve, and the shining eyes and pink cheeks made her almost beautiful.
When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father. Then he pressed the thorn into her heart. It was true, just as he had said, it did cause a piercing pain, but it slipped in quickly and then, suddenly, a sweetness she had never felt or imagined before tingled through her. It was bittersweet, but the sweetness was the stronger. She thought of the Shepherd's words, It is so happy to love, and her pale, sallow cheeks suddenly glowed pink and her eyes shone. For a moment Much-Afraid did not look afraid at all. The twisted mouth had relaxed into a happy curve, and the shining eyes and pink cheeks made her almost beautiful. Thank you, thank you, she cried, and knelt at the Shepherd's feet.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport. Think of your training as a vehicle to improve performance, not just to improve strength.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport. Think of your training as a vehicle to improve performance, not just to improve strength. Many athletes have neglected strength training because they do not fully understand the performance-enhancing value of strength in sports such as baseball, tennis, or soccer.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport. Think of your training as a vehicle to improve performance, not just to improve strength. Many athletes have neglected strength training because they do not fully understand the performance-enhancing value of strength in sports such as baseball, tennis, or soccer. The key from the athlete's standpoint is for the training to make sense.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport. Think of your training as a vehicle to improve performance, not just to improve strength. Many athletes have neglected strength training because they do not fully understand the performance-enhancing value of strength in sports such as baseball, tennis, or soccer. The key from the athlete's standpoint is for the training to make sense. The key from the coach's standpoint is to make the training make sense to the athlete.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport. Think of your training as a vehicle to improve performance, not just to improve strength. Many athletes have neglected strength training because they do not fully understand the performance-enhancing value of strength in sports such as baseball, tennis, or soccer. The key from the athlete's standpoint is for the training to make sense. The key from the coach's standpoint is to make the training make sense to the athlete. A training Olympic gold medalist Kayla Harrison is a great example of how sports-general training can benefit an athlete.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport. Think of your training as a vehicle to improve performance, not just to improve strength. Many athletes have neglected strength training because they do not fully understand the performance-enhancing value of strength in sports such as baseball, tennis, or soccer. The key from the athlete's standpoint is for the training to make sense. The key from the coach's standpoint is to make the training make sense to the athlete. A training Olympic gold medalist Kayla Harrison is a great example of how sports-general training can benefit an athlete. In Kayla's program we did not need to imitate the throws of judo; we simply needed to get her stronger in basic movement patterns.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport. Think of your training as a vehicle to improve performance, not just to improve strength. Many athletes have neglected strength training because they do not fully understand the performance-enhancing value of strength in sports such as baseball, tennis, or soccer. The key from the athlete's standpoint is for the training to make sense. The key from the coach's standpoint is to make the training make sense to the athlete. A training Olympic gold medalist Kayla Harrison is a great example of how sports-general training can benefit an athlete. In Kayla's program we did not need to imitate the throws of judo; we simply needed to get her stronger in basic movement patterns. The important thing for Kayla was to develop strength in pushing, pulling, rotating, squatting, and lunging.
When training for strength, never compromise back safety to make the body position of the exercise more specific. As you begin to explore the concept of functional training for sport, keep an open mind about how and why athletes move in your sport. Think of your training as a vehicle to improve performance, not just to improve strength. Many athletes have neglected strength training because they do not fully understand the performance-enhancing value of strength in sports such as baseball, tennis, or soccer. The key from the athlete's standpoint is for the training to make sense. The key from the coach's standpoint is to make the training make sense to the athlete. A training Olympic gold medalist Kayla Harrison is a great example of how sports-general training can benefit an athlete. In Kayla's program we did not need to imitate the throws of judo; we simply needed to get her stronger in basic movement patterns. The important thing for Kayla was to develop strength in pushing, pulling, rotating, squatting, and lunging. How we chose to do that was based not on sport but on injury history and sport demands.
When viewed through the functional anatomy lens, all the muscles act eccentrically in the first sequence to stop a movement and then milliseconds later act concentrically to create a movement.
When viewed through the functional anatomy lens, all the muscles act eccentrically in the first sequence to stop a movement and then milliseconds later act concentrically to create a movement. If these concepts begin to make sense, you are on your way to understanding the science of functional anatomy and the concept of functional training.
When viewed through the functional anatomy lens, all the muscles act eccentrically in the first sequence to stop a movement and then milliseconds later act concentrically to create a movement. If these concepts begin to make sense, you are on your way to understanding the science of functional anatomy and the concept of functional training. When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running.

When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action.
When viewed through the functional anatomy lens, all the muscles act eccentrically in the first sequence to stop a movement and then milliseconds later act concentrically to create a movement. If these concepts begin to make sense, you are on your way to understanding the science of functional anatomy and the concept of functional training. When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform).
When viewed through the functional anatomy lens, all the muscles act eccentrically in the first sequence to stop a movement and then milliseconds later act concentrically to create a movement. If these concepts begin to make sense, you are on your way to understanding the science of functional anatomy and the concept of functional training. When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground.
When viewed through the functional anatomy lens, all the muscles act eccentrically in the first sequence to stop a movement and then milliseconds later act concentrically to create a movement. If these concepts begin to make sense, you are on your way to understanding the science of functional anatomy and the concept of functional training. When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional.

The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional.
When viewed through the functional anatomy lens, all the muscles act eccentrically in the first sequence to stop a movement and then milliseconds later act concentrically to create a movement. If these concepts begin to make sense, you are on your way to understanding the science of functional anatomy and the concept of functional training. When an athlete performs a nonfunctional exercise such as a leg extension, she is using a muscle action and nervous system pattern that is never employed when walking or running. The athlete is by definition performing an open-chain muscle action. Open-chain means the foot is not in contact with the ground (or a stable platform). To exercise a muscle as it will be used, you need to close the chain and allow the muscles to work as they would when the foot is on the ground. In regard to the lower extremity, open-chain or single-joint can be considered almost synonymous with nonfunctional. The Functional Training Controversy Revisited Over the past 20 years, there has been a major shift toward attempting to make training more functional. Coaches changed from a very bilaterally based, barbell-oriented program to a program that places more emphasis on unilateral exercise and incorporates more dumbbell and kettlebell work.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose. So when we apply that term to training f or sports we are talking about purposeful training for sports.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose. So when we apply that term to training f or sports we are talking about purposeful training for sports. The idea of functional training or functional exercise actually originated in the sports medicine world.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose. So when we apply that term to training f or sports we are talking about purposeful training for sports. The idea of functional training or functional exercise actually originated in the sports medicine world. As is often the case, the thoughts and exercises used in rehab found their way from the physical therapy clinic and athletic training room into the weight room.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose. So when we apply that term to training f or sports we are talking about purposeful training for sports. The idea of functional training or functional exercise actually originated in the sports medicine world. As is often the case, the thoughts and exercises used in rehab found their way from the physical therapy clinic and athletic training room into the weight room. The most basic thought was that the exercises used to return an athlete to health might also be the best exercises to maintain and improve health.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose. So when we apply that term to training f or sports we are talking about purposeful training for sports. The idea of functional training or functional exercise actually originated in the sports medicine world. As is often the case, the thoughts and exercises used in rehab found their way from the physical therapy clinic and athletic training room into the weight room. The most basic thought was that the exercises used to return an athlete to health might also be the best exercises to maintain and improve health. Since the concept of functional training was first applied to sports it has been misunderstood and mislabeled by many athletes and coaches.

The idea of functional training or functional exercise actually originated in the sports medicine world. As is often the case, the thoughts and exercises used in rehab found their way from the physical therapy clinic and athletic training room into the weight room. The most basic thought was that the exercises used to return an athlete to health might also be the best exercises to maintain and improve health. Since the concept of functional training was first applied to sports it has been misunderstood and mislabeled by many athletes and coaches. Terms such as sport specific, which implies that certain movements and movement patterns are specific to individual sports, have been used to describe some functional training concepts.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose. So when we apply that term to training f or sports we are talking about purposeful training for sports. The idea of functional training or functional exercise actually originated in the sports medicine world. As is often the case, the thoughts and exercises used in rehab found their way from the physical therapy clinic and athletic training room into the weight room. The most basic thought was that the exercises used to return an athlete to health might also be the best exercises to maintain and improve health. Since the concept of functional training was first applied to sports it has been misunderstood and mislabeled by many athletes and coaches. Terms such as sport specific, which implies that certain movements and movement patterns are specific to individual sports, have been used to describe some functional training concepts. But sport-specific training takes place with the athlete on the mat, field, or court, whereas in strength and conditioning we work to get the athlete stronger and to improve specific conditioning.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose. So when we apply that term to training f or sports we are talking about purposeful training for sports. The idea of functional training or functional exercise actually originated in the sports medicine world. As is often the case, the thoughts and exercises used in rehab found their way from the physical therapy clinic and athletic training room into the weight room. The most basic thought was that the exercises used to return an athlete to health might also be the best exercises to maintain and improve health. Since the concept of functional training was first applied to sports it has been misunderstood and mislabeled by many athletes and coaches. Terms such as sport specific, which implies that certain movements and movement patterns are specific to individual sports, have been used to describe some functional training concepts. But sport-specific training takes place with the athlete on the mat, field, or court, whereas in strength and conditioning we work to get the athlete stronger and to improve specific conditioning. Indeed, functional training may be more accurately represented by the term sports-general training than by the term sport-specific training.
When we use the word function we are saying that something has a purpose. So when we apply that term to training f or sports we are talking about purposeful training for sports. The idea of functional training or functional exercise actually originated in the sports medicine world. As is often the case, the thoughts and exercises used in rehab found their way from the physical therapy clinic and athletic training room into the weight room. The most basic thought was that the exercises used to return an athlete to health might also be the best exercises to maintain and improve health. Since the concept of functional training was first applied to sports it has been misunderstood and mislabeled by many athletes and coaches. Terms such as sport specific, which implies that certain movements and movement patterns are specific to individual sports, have been used to describe some functional training concepts. But sport-specific training takes place with the athlete on the mat, field, or court, whereas in strength and conditioning we work to get the athlete stronger and to improve specific conditioning. Indeed, functional training may be more accurately represented by the term sports-general training than by the term sport-specific training. Although we may deal with the smaller details of sport -specific adaptations in this book, it is important to understand that most sports possess far more similarities than differences.

When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father.
Won't it hurt if you put it into my heart? He answered gently, It is so sharp that it slips in very quickly. Then she looked at the Shepherd's face and repeated his words to herself. When the seed of Love in your heart is ready to bloom, you will be loved in return, ä and a strange new courage entered into her. She suddenly stepped forward, bared her heart, and said, Please plant the seed here in my heart. His face lit up with a glad smile and he said with a note of joy in his voice, Now you will be able to go with me to the High Places and be a citizen in the Kingdom of my Father. Then he pressed the thorn into her heart. It was true, just as he had said, it did cause a piercing pain, but it slipped in quickly and then, suddenly, a sweetness she had never felt or imagined before tingled through her.
You are not to take anything with you, only leave everything in order.
You are not to take anything with you, only leave everything in order. Do not tell anyone about it, for a journey to the High Places needs to be a secret matter.
You are not to take anything with you, only leave everything in order. Do not tell anyone about it, for a journey to the High Places needs to be a secret matter. I cannot now give you the exact time when we are to start for the mountains, but it will be soon, and you must be ready to follow me whenever I come to the cottage and call.

I will give you a secret sign. I shall sing one of the Shepherd's songs as I pass the cottage, and it will contain a special message for you.

When you hear it, come at once and follow me to the trysting place.
